title: What is the worst Beatles song? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m surprised at some of the answers on here. Maggie Mae, for example - sure, it’s not great, but it clearly wasn’t meant to be. It’s there to give a sense of irreverence that was the Beatles at that time and, like Dig It, it provides the album with some of the randomness of the film whilst managing not to sabotage it. Ob la di and Yellow Submarine - I can understand people not caring for either but to dismiss them as the worst Beatles’ song is again missing the point. They are huge and iconic and the kitchness is clearly intentional. They are revered by people who are not necessarily Beatles fans at all, by people that have never heard of Run for your Life or I Don’t Want to Spoil the Party. Yellow Submarine was a huge gamble because it showed the Beatles weren’t afraid to do something outside the norm, so different from their usual output. Revolution 9 - again, a dreadful ‘song’ (if you choose to call it such) but important. What other band would have done that? Skip it for the sake of your ears and sanity but celebrate it at the same time. I am less convinced, though, by tracks such as Wild Honey Pie which would have been better shortened and used as an ending to a more substantial track (a bit like the Heba, Heba halloa at the end of Hello Goodbye. The Beatles at that time had become very self indulgent, and I could easily live without many tracks on the White Album. But what I really find annoying are the tracks that don’t seem to go anywhere, as if they never bothered to finish them. Your Mother Should Know is potentially a great song, the opening is very catchy. The trouble is, the opening is all there is. Four phrases and you have all the melody. McCartney sings ‘Say it again’ and that is virtually what you get, repetition, apart from a middle that is so vague and unmelodic you wonder why he never bothered to try a little harder, not helped by a lyric that doesn’t mean anything but sounds as if it does. I also find some of the indulgence of Lennon lyrically incredibly annoying. I’m surprised nobody’s mentioned ‘Happiness is a Warm Gun’ where lines like ‘a soap impression of his wife which he ate’ etc. etc. are too long to be self-parodying. But for me the worst song by far is ‘Don’t Pass me By.’ Played badly, recorded badly, sung badly, even produced badly; it swings like a well-heeled paving stone, out of tune even by Ringo’s standards, banal lyrics and a melody that you’d make up on the spot as an example of a cliched country song. Whatever the magic that turned Octupus’s Garden into a listenable song against all the odds wasn’t present on the day they recorded Don’t Pass me By. Resist the message of the title and pass it by. And vote it the worst song. FURTHER TO READING COMMENTS I agree with anybody who says this is an uncool process, but I never asked the question…the main difficulty with it is that, if you think a song is bad, unless you are some kind of congenital fool or have a death wish you’re not likely to be in the habit of listening to what you consider the worst Beatle tracks; so to answer this question you probably have to write about tracks you haven’t actually heard in years. Therefore, to be fair, I listened to ‘Don’t Pass me By,’ trying to be positive about it. So here goes:- It contains the lyric:- ‘I'm sorry that I doubted you,I was so unfair.You were in a car crash,And you lost your hair.’ I find this interesting because way back in those heady days of love there was an odd need many of felt to prove that Paul MacCartney had died in a car crash. We played bits of recording backwards and analysed record covers to the nth degree in what I now suspect was a subconscious competition to see how contrived we could all be, under the illusion we were being serious; curiously the one line that specifically mentioned a car crash nobody ever mentioned at all*. This may indicate that the track, even then, was considered so bad even self-appointed adolescent sleuths couldn’t bear to listen to it. I also note the abysmally overdubbed fiddle was played by Jack Fallon. Jack was an agent, who ran ‘Cana Variety.’ He specialised in singing pianists, and in the early nineties I worked for him. I asked him about Don’t Pass me By and he told me he’d sold the violin on which he’d played for several hundred pounds, even though it was a cheap instrument. His wife commented that he was an idiot as he could have sold them any violin (‘they wouldn’t have known’.) He showed me a typed contract which dated from about 1963 stating he’d booked: ‘The Beatles (quartet)’ for the sum of £15. The fact that they used an agent playing a cheap instrument rather than a professional on a strad says it all. Listening to it again after all these years I believe this track is truly awful. Even if it was Alf Cutler and the Wurzels or the 1992 Albanian World Cup Squad it would be an embarrassment. But good luck to all those people that like it. As has been pointed out, you have a right to your opinion however wrong it might be. *According to Wikipedia the line about ‘losing your hair’ IS cited by proponents of the "Paul is Dead" urban legend. But I don’t remember that the first time around, probably because I was too busy inhaling smoking dried banana skins in a kaftan.

Hi. May I confess, I haven’t read all the existing answers yet - 56 at this point - so I may accidentally repeat someone. Apologies in advance, if I do. My answer: The Long and Winding Road as violated by Phil Spector on the original Let It Be album. The true song itself is near perfection, as proven by every other performance McCartney’s done, including on Let It Be - Naked. The ruination of the original came through the work of Phil Spector. Those strings, real or other!! Spector committed one of the most invasive arrangements and pieces of production I can think of. It says “ignore McCartney - look at me - aren’t I beautiful and smarmy?” Yep, there’s a good reason why McCartney has never (to my knowledge) performed this genius song in any way resembling Spector’s abomination. How can I claim it’s a great song, yet denounce it as their worst song? Well, if many Beatles songs are great thanks to the contributions of George Martin, then sadly they could also be ruined by Spector. We need to remember, John sent the Let It Be tapes to Spector, and the others didn’t even know he was playing around with them. Can you imagine how Paul must’ve reacted when he heard yet another of his genius compositions trashed, only for it to then be released to the world as if he wanted it like that? I wonder how many times he said “Actually, that’s not how I wanted it - I hate those strings! So don’t blame me!” Now, please allow me to repeat, the oft-used “I’m surprised by many of the entries” opening line. :) How do we define “worst song”? It’s good to hear the songs people dislike, but that’s all bonus, because “dislike the most” does not equal “worst”. Experimental pieces, like Revolution 9 and Wild Honey Pie, shouldn’t get trashed just because they fall outside our norms for 3 minute rock-pop songs. They may not pass audition for “Liverpool, You’ve Got Talent!”, but they are incredibly well constructed Beatles songs that keep reminding us why The Beatles remain unsurpassed in revolutionising music. Composers like Stockhausen and Cage had been creating experimental music for some time, so this stuff was not new. However, as early as 1966 with Revolver, The Beatles were already able to assimilate obscure, high-brow experimentalism into their own creativity and produce material that was among best of breed. If you really think these are the worst Beatles songs, get your best audio gear, best headphones, perfect listening conditions, listen to the details and lose yourself in the music - hear what’s going on - ask yourself, “How are they doing that - what’s happening?” Ponder: “Which later, highly respected artists may have learned their craft, style and success by listening to these pieces?” You might become a fan! :) Playful pieces, such as Yellow Submarine, Octopus’ Garden, Don’t Pass Me By, Ob La Di Ob La Da and Piggies are not “worst” just because some people think they’re silly or inane. For me, pieces like these are part song and part scenes from imagined movies or musicals. Let’s think about Don’t Pass Me By, which seems to be popular among these answers. That fiddle! It’s not just an instrument, it’s also a musical prop for the song! We’re no longer in our living room or at a concert, we’re in Hicksville America, yee-ha! And Ringo, he’s not trying to sing like Sinatra, Presley, nor even himself. He’s being the scrappiest, loneliest, sorriest hick of them all! At least he has his feeble hick band with him, squeezed into his dusty front room, giving him their all as they do their bit for our Sunday afternoon “Ma & Pa Kettle” movie. Fantastic! Let yourself be transported into the scene, rather than judge the “musical quality” - after all, the quality was intentional hicked for your listening pleasure. I’ll stop the whinging there. Thank you. Please have a good day!

There are a number of contenders - unhappily quire a lot of them are by George (which I regret: I’m a George fan and his best stuff is fab.) Among the contenders is Blue Jay Way - a dismal dirge. He was trying to evoke a sense of boredom and dissipation and succeeded brilliantly. Then there is Only A Northern Song - sorry, it’s abysmal. Let’s give George a break here and consider other contenders. I’m leaving aside things like Revolution #9 because it is not, actually, a song. And Wild Honey Pie - similarly, is really just a squib. Why Don’t We Do It In The Road is a failure - John was brilliant at doing this kind of ‘feel’ song (eg Come Together) and Paul wanted to do one. Should have been talked out of it. What’s The New Mary Jane is awful, but that’s not fair because the Fabs never worked it up into a proper song - if you listen to demos of songs that did make it on to record (Mean Mr Mustard) you might think they were worthless too, and then the Beatles would fettle them to something wonderful. Run For Your Life (on Rubber Soul) is wretched - lazy, sloppy, badly played, and unpleasant in tone. You can see how it happened. John was obviously thinking of a past triumph - clearly You Can’t Do That (if you haven’t listened to that recently, go back and have another listen - it is magnificent) and thought he’d reprise his achievement. He blew it. And rather badly. There are other Beatles songs that are bad for various reasons, but which don’t plumb the depths of some of these (honourable mentions - Maxwell’s Silver Hammer, Savoy Truffle, It’s All Too Much - sorry George again). But the more interesting point is that good Beatles songs outnumber bad ones by a large margin, and great Beatles songs are a very large proportion of the oevre. My view? The Beatles had the best strike rate of great tracks of anybody ever.

It’s hard to choose 5 bad songs from the greatest band of all time (in my opinion), but here we go.  From least worst to worst: 5. Maggie Mae - Let It Be A 40 second rendition of an old Liverpool song that is… not so great. It sticks out like a sore thumb when you realize that it’s surrounded by two masterpieces: “Let It Be” before and “I’ve Got A Feeling” afterwards. 4. Maxwell’s Silver Hammer - Abbey Road During his prime, Paul McCartney took a detour of rich songs with deep meaning to make a song about a kid who murders people with a silver hammer. Luckily, McCartney would redeem himself if Abbey Road with the very next track: Oh! Darling! However, this song is for some reason put in between George Harrison’s masterpiece Something and then the aforementioned Oh! Darling. In my opinion, it shouldn’t have made the album at all since it feels so out of place. 3. Within You, Without You - Sgt. Pepper George Harrison was a fantastic songwriter. You couldn’t tell from this. Coming off his great contributions on Revolver and Rubber Soul, this entry to the finest Beatles album there is just doesn’t sound like The Beatles. In my opinion, it’s the only disappointing entry on the album. 2. You Know The Name (Look Up The Number) - Single God awful. That’s all I really have to say. Revolution 9 - The White AlbumThis may be the only Beatle song that I would label as pure garbage. Almost every Beatles song, good or bad, have some redeemable qualities in them. Revolution 9 does not. It is one of the most bizarre piece of rubbish I’ve ever listened to. Yoko and John really went out of their way to close out the album on a poor note here. I’m not a fan of it in the slightest. I will never again listen to the entirety of The White Album because of this song. I skip it and go straight to Good Night every time.

The worst Beatles song is one of those those which people did not understand. How can you understand Revolution 9? Ok, they tried, or just John Lennon, tried to experiment with psychedelia and take it even further. Which I don’t think he did quite well. He must be really high when he got this idea. But the concept of psychedelia really is based on the effects of psychedelic drugs,which often causes experience of visual and auditory shifts, altered state of consciousness, or what we refer to as being “high” as in high up in cloud nine singing and dancing with unicorn pooping rainbows and sneezing candies. Things like that. Please take note that I’ve never been high before, and the strongest drug that was ever induced to me was general anesthesia when I was only 5. So I never really have experienced these kinds of things. But in Psychology, you will somehow understand the effects of psychedelics. There is a reason why psychedelia was not so much of a boom! compared to it’s sister genre. But this kind of style—the psychedelia—gave birth to newer better styles. Take Stairway to Heaven by Led Zeppelin for example, I can distinguish five or six different changes throughout the same song and it’s not even psychedelia its in the hard rock genre, but the rhythm and melodic change throughout the song is characteristic of psychedelic rock—only that it’s not so much of a smooth transition it’s often wavy. And now here comes our current pop songs sounding more and more monotonous, perhaps we need a new wave of psychedelia just to insert diversification? Oh, wait… I’m a little off topic. Anyway, Revolution 9 was the worst Beatles track, I don’t even consider it a song. The first time I heard it, I thought my record was broken. But no. It’s just really that. Some silly things the rich and famous do and people just support because they are rich and famous. In fairness to the Beatles, they have been very creative and quite fearless in their musical experiment. Only that psychedelia was a bit coo coo, well it was really intended to.

I am definitely a Beatles fan and of course the question is completely subjective. As I perused the answers given by people I noticed I was fond of quite a few song mentioned. As always with that which is a subjective choice, many do not care to mention “Why” it is the worst song they recorded. When I saw this question only one song leapt to the forefront of my consciousness. It is a song from the ‘White Album” and written and recorded by Paul McCartney. It is wholly repetitive piece which drove me insane. I had a friend that played it incessantly. I personally have not listened to it voluntarily in forty three years. It is short and simple; 1:42 of twelve-bar blues that begins with three different percussion elements (a hand banging on the back of an acoustic guitar, handclaps, and drums) and features McCartney's increasingly raucous vocal repeating a simple lyric with only two different lines. McCartney wrote the song after seeing two monkeys copulating in the street while on retreat in Rishikesh, India. He marvel led in the simplicity of this natural scenario when compared to the emotional turmoil of human relationships. He later said “A male [monkey] just hopped on the back of this female and gave her one, as they say in the vernacular. Within two or three seconds he hopped off again and looked around as if to say "It wasn't me!" and she looked around as if there'd been some mild disturbance ... And I thought ... that's how simple the act of procreation is ... We have horrendous problems with it, and yet animals don't.” Not only is the song foul but it caused strife within the group, mainly that Paul would write and record his own songs with no one else present. From what I had read of Paul’s explanation, everyone was busy except for Ringo when this was performed. Sounds reasonable to me but these are humans with egos arguing so what is to be expected. Here it is in all its glory. 1 minute 42 seconds of ‘Why Don’t We Do It In The Road”. Here are the lyrics: Why don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadNo one will be watching usWhy don't we do it in the road Why don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadNo one will be watching usWhy don't we do it in the road Why don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadWhy don't we do it in the roadNo one will be watching usWhy don't we do it in the road And as I am looking at the lyrics I am getting nauseous and feel as though I need to drill a few holes in my head.

Like many, I was quite surprised by some of the responses. To each his own. I’m not going to consider any short, inconsequential songs in my answer - so no “Maggie Mae”, “Flying”, etc. (I happen to like “Dig It” and “Wild Honey Pie”, by the way.) I’m also not including any covers or pre-1965 songs. I couldn’t resist this question, but would rather not wade through the early records - which I know less intimately - to determine which ones to include. Finally, my list only includes official canonical releases (no” If You’ve Got Trouble”, etc). Disclaimer out of the way, on to the list. Worst Beatles songs to me are: “Revolution 9” - It’s not even a song, so it may not even belong here. (“What Goes On” could sub) In any case, if it were under 2 minutes, maybe I’d regard it as an interesting experiment. At 8 minutes or whatever, well….oh no Yoko. “You Know My Name” - I guess you had to be there to appreciate the joke. “Don’t Pass Me By” - simply awful in every way, as others have pointed out. “Blue Jay Way” - tuneless, morose, dreary, monotonous. George certainly succeeded in capturing the feeling of waiting all night for someone to turn up. “Within You, Without You” - Pretty much the same as the previous - just longer. I’d like to offer a couple of variations. Worst Lennon/McCartney Beatles songs. It looks like I beat up on George and Ringo on my main list, so let’s give them a break here: “Another Girl”, “Run For Your Life” - lyrics are unforgivable, “She’s Leaving Home”, “Your Mother Should Know”, “Maxwell’s Silver Hammer.” The other variation would be, “worst popular Beatles Songs”. I eschew the word “overrated” because most of these either have lots of detractors, weren’t hits, or were simply never rated very highly to begin with - if that makes sense. All appear on singles and/or compilation albums, hence the term, “popular”. Dishonorable mention goes to: “Eight Days A Week” - Contrived and formulaic, just super lame. The title is the best thing about it. “Across The Universe” - weak melody, insipid performance, sophomoric lyrics. know a lot of people like this, but I don’t get what’s so great about it. “The Long And Winding Road” - yeah the Spector treatment was overdone, but the song itself is too maudlin for my taste. “Old Brown Shoe” - listened to it recently, not as bad as I thought. It’s got some great guitar, but still not quite good enough for a B-side. “Octopus’s Garden” - sorry Ringo, but no…. great drummer and a lovely bloke, though.

There are a few Beatle originals that don’t really do it for me, and that I don’t care if I never hear again. They’re not awful, and most are pretty good when compared with other music at the time, just not compared with other Beatle songs. Here they are in no particular order, and no, Revolution 9 isn’t on the list. I love that one. When I Get Home (This one annoys me, especially the “woo oh woo hi!”)Run For Your Life (Hate the lyrics - so misogynist)Hold Me Tight (Gives me a headache)What You’re Doing (Too repetitive, no real melody)I Call Your Name (Terrible guitar solo, weak melody)Revolution 1 (acoustic version) (Love the single, but this version is dull)Wild Honey Pie (Horrible. Maybe their worst. No tune at all and interrupts the flow of an otherwise superb album side)Maxwell’s Silver Hammer (Cloying. Too cute)What Goes On (Sounds bad in comparison to the great songs around it on Rubber Soul)You Know My Name (Look Up the Number) (Fun the first few times but then I don’t need to hear it again)The Long and Winding Road (Overly lush, trying too hard to be significant, long, dull)Love Me Do (Historically important but a lame song, really. Very repetitive. Sounds like I could have written it)Tell Me What You See (Hate the lyrics, but cool electric piano)Blue Jay Way (Long, ponderous, boring, hate the production)Flying (Harmless but dumb. Well below the group’s usual standards)Your Mother Should Know (See “Maxwell’s Silver Hammer” above)I’ll Get You (Melody isn’t strong, poorly performed with lyric errors)Hello Goodbye (See “Maxwell’s Silver Hammer”)Helter Skelter (I appreciate what they tried to do but it’s too loud and gives me a headache)It’s Only Love (Lennon said the lyric was dumb and he hated the song. He was his own harshest critic but in this case he was right).That’s about 20 songs out of nearly 200 originals they wrote (Lennon/McCartney, plus George and Ringo’s songs). The other 90% or so are great!

For me, in general, the worst Beatles songs are the McCartney songs that Lennon referred to as “granny” songs. I came to these conclusions independently, long before internet made me aware of Lennon’s or other people’s opinions. There are also several songs that bore me shirtless, that other’s think are brilliant. These tend to be the McCartney hit songs. I know that most people will disagree with me, especially about Michelle and Here, There and Everywhere, which are considered some of the finest Beatles’ songs. So, here is my list. Don’t get upset. It’s only personal taste: 10. Revolution number 9 - I know of nobody that has listened to this track more than once.9. Wild Honey Pie - Throw away filler8. Honey Pie - McCartney music hall granny music7. The Long and Winding Road - McCartney dirge.6. Yesterday- Along with Michelle, considered one of the great Beatle song. Well crafted pablum.5. Your Mother Should know - McCartney granny music.4. Michelle - Another slick, well crafted song others love, but I skip.3. Here, There and Everywhere - Dirgy well crafted pop song.2. Maxwell’s Silver Hammer - Granny to the max. Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da - Considered by many to be the most objectionable Beatles song.One might get the feeling that I despise all McCartney songs, but this isn’t the case. Paperback Writer and I’ve Just Seen a Face are two of my favorite Beatle songs, but, in the great Lennon guy/McCartney guy binary division of personality types, I’m a Lennon guy.

They worst Beatles songs? That’s a loaded question. It’s all based on opinion in’t it.? I grew up listening to a radio when The Beatles came on with “She Loves You”.  And when “I Want to Hold Your Hand” came on.  I was up East in the snow in Mass. I was 10 or 12. And when those songs came on, I was in inner hysteria. I had found my music, not my eldest sister’s Elvis Presley hysteria in the 50’s, nor my other older sister’s white pop radio crap. They were 4 and 8 years older. Then suddenly Ed Sullivan! Those songs coming out of that radio. Damn there were and still are my band, my boys. Th best, the cutest, the funniest. Unless you were one of those hysterical fans like me, you wouldn’t understand. My sister took me to the drive-in with her boyfriend when “A Hard Day’s Night” came out. I was in the back seat, and from the credits all the way through I screamed and cried and felt I would faint, I was in a tizzy, a manic love and excitement. I loved that movie. (note: when they got me home I was still hysterical. My Mom gave me a tranquilizer and put me to bed.) Anyway…….I don’t have too many songs that I don’t like. Especially from their early albums. And especially from “Beatles For Sale” ,“Rubber Soul” or “Revolver”. I moved to Europe in 1964 and lived there for almost 5 years, in Italy and in Germany. My Beatles albums are the European releases EMI which carried 12+ tracks, much different than the U.S. hodgepoge of make a buck releases. The EMI discs were vetted by the Beatles, the track placements were seriously determined before the discs were released so they have a flow and consistent theme and the songs creatively placed. From “Beatles For Sale” (with that gorgeous photo on the cover), I loved all those songs. The only clinker has to be “Mr. Moonlight”. They just sound straind, and the song not written by them, the lyrics I don’t enjoy or the melody. From “Help” I loved the whole album. The beginning song is relevant and just explodes in your brain. From “Rubber Soul” (my favorite album) once again I love every song. From “Revolver”, I liked all the songs, again. From “Sgt Pepper’s “ I again love these songs. Except for two that stop the flow, down right pause the fun of the album. “She’s Leaving Home”is o.k. but I listened to it rarely. and George’s “Within You or Without You” “The Magical Mystery Tour” was not an album in Europe. Instead it was released as a book with 45’s hidden inside. Released in 1967, It is a small book with 0 pages of photos and cartoons showing the bus tour. Th 45s are from Odeon and EMI. There are two discs, 2 songs on each disc. Disc 1: Side one…..Magical Mystery Tour, Your Mother Should Know. Side two…. I am The Walrus. Record 2…. Side one…The Fool On The Hill and Flying. Side two….Blue Jay Way.Of course you know the clinkers on this. Sorry George. “Flying” and “Blue Jay Way” are filler. Blue Jay Way is junk and noise that is aa headache Nxt “The White Album” Holy Baloney…..aa..lot of crap on here. “Wild Honey Pie” shows they could put all kinds of crap out in public. Zepers. “ Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da …….I can understand why Lennon wanted to choke Paul over this nonsense tripe. Considering he made the band do take over take…..George and Ringo hated this stupid song. Lennon left, went out and got drunk. Returned and declared…”THIS is how the piano should sound!!!” And proceeded to play it as you hear it now. And much better than Paul’s original melody” A stinker was that song. “Yer Blues” I didn’t like ”Everybody's Got Something To Hide Except Me And My Monkey “. They sound great, but I don’t like the song. Helter Skelter is another one that is a waste. Hate that song. And of course everyone’s favorite to hate. Revolution 9. yoko must have slipped him some mickey’s. Crap. My opinion only. A couple of stinkers is not bad from a catloque of 200 masterpiecers.

A very easy question: If You’ve Got Trouble. Throwaway trash, which the band rightly considered not worth releasing.What’s the New Mary Jane. Lennon was proud of this sloppy exercise in arbitrariness but when a song is even worse than ‘Rocky Raccoon’ or ‘Bungalow Bill’, it’s not surprising it never got issued.That Means A Lot. Interesting experiment but McCartney couldn’t get the melody to work.12-Bar Original. A pointless blues jam.Carnival of Light. Nothing I have heard about this free improvisation makes me think that the Beatles could possibly have made something interesting with this.…Unless you meant ‘songs they actually released at the time’, in which case it’s: Run For Your Life. Dumb, not very tuneful, misogynistic rewrite of a forgettable Elvis song. Unworthy in every way of the band and its writer.Piggies. Mean-spirited, irritating ditty by Harrison in maximum-judgemental mode. It’s not their fault that it inspired Charles Manson, but if it hadn’t been on the album he wouldn’t have been able to be inspired by it. Ian Macdonald records that when Harrison was recording the song, he started playing another melody on the harpsichord (possibly ‘Something’, I’ll check) and producer Chris Thomas commented ‘That’s nice,’ before adding hopefully, ‘…couldn’t we do that instead?’Maxwell’s Silver Hammer. Stupid joke song given a lavish production it didn’t deserve, like a turd on a golden platter.Blue Jay Way: George, boredom is not a promising subject for a song, as this song demonstrates. The fact that anyone can think that the majestic ‘Within You Without You’ is inferior to this, is baffling to me.Hello, Goodbye: There’s good mindless pop songs and there’s bad mindless pop songs. This is one idea stretched out for three and a half minutes. McCartney has claimed that it’s an attempt to explore the fundamental dualities in the universe and blah blah blah. That’s crap. It’s just dumb.

"Maggie Mae". In 2001 the rec.music.beatles usenet newsgroup ran an elimination tournament among hard-core Beatles fans to determine the worst Beatles song from the original studio albums. The results were as follows from 10th worst to worst: 10. Matchbox 9. Act Naturally 8. Don't Pass Me By 7. Honey Don't  6. Revolution 9 5. Mr. Moonlight 4. A Taste Of Honey  3. Wild Honey Pie  2. Dig It 1. Maggie Mae Note that "Maggie Mae" here is not related to the similarly-titled Rod Stewart song, but is the Beatles' version of the traditional English ballad. It loses points for several reasons: At just 40 seconds it is just a snippet of a song;It is a goofy, addled performance;It is placed immediately following the timeless title track of the Let It Be album, breaking the mood and coming off like a fart in church;It was chosen for inclusion and placed there by Phil Spector, whose work on that album is ill-regarded by many, notably Paul McCartney."Dig It", the runner-up in this worst-song contest, appears on the same album as another short snippet and is disliked for many of the same reasons, though it is a Lennon composition rather than a traditional. "Wild Honey Pie" is, again, a sub-one minute sketch of a song by McCartney. The only full-length songs on this list that are not covers are the Ringo composition "Don't Pass Me By" and the experimental sound collage "Revolution 9", mostly a Lennon work.

In my opinion, there is no “worst Beatles song” simply because no matter what they put out, it was commercially successful. As it is said in the other answers, most of the snippets of songs and the covers are the bad songs, so for my answer I will exclude them here. I am also excluding songs that many people consider to be their worst already to avoid parity (aka Revolution 9, Yellow Submarine, Ringo’s songs, etc.). Basically, I’m rewriting the question a little bit to ask, “What is the worst Beatles song that people actually think is good?” So without those choices, my consensus “worst Beatles song” is… All Together Now WAIT WAIT WAIT!!!! Hear me out! Now before people come screaming at me that I’m criticizing a popular, lovable song, I’d like to give my reasons. Although some people find this song to be a decent listen, it sounds so much like a quick children’s song with no meaning. It seems like a follow up to Yellow Submarine, but intended for an EVEN YOUNGER audience. The guitar is not bad, but it can’t save the childish and monotonous lyrics. It legitimately sounds like they wrote it in five minutes, and unlike quickly written songs like You Won't See Me and A Hard Day’s Night (which were actually written is 3 hours and 6 hours respectively), it doesn’t hit the mark as a good hit. Now of course this was for the Yellow Submarine movie, and they were asked to write a closing song, so they penned this up, but I feel that they could have done so much better. I hope that helped you out! Feel free to let me know what you guys think of All Together Now, and tell me what you guys think is worse.

Worst is relative. There are few songs by the Beatles that am I inclined to actually skip because I hate them that much. Even the ones I dislike still seem to be part of the bigger picture in the context of the album. Still, there are some Beatles songs I wouldn’t want to introduce a new fan to: Nothing too out of the ordinary here: Mr. Moonlight — Piano Red’s original is marginally better (as seen here) but I just don’t think it’s a very good song.Everybody’s Trying to be my Baby — Carl Perkin’s just way better than George at this song (here) I think the Beatles put more life into it on the BBC CD.Dig it — There wasn’t much point to including this on the album. It’s a piece of a much bigger improv jam (a version of which can be found here) and never goes anywhere. Of all the “scraps” to come from the Let it Be sessions, why this one was chosen doesn’t make a lot of sense.Goodnight — Ringo does not do a very good job at this song, which is about the last thing you’d expect the Beatles to record. I do wonder, though, if John could have pulled it off in the style of Julia. It was, after all, soft of a lullaby for his son.Kansas City-Hey Hey Hey Hey [Medley] — The original is superior. I like Paul’s Little Richard imitations, but the Beatles don’t add anything to the song.Personally, there are some songs I just don’t like, but I can see why others like them: Eight Days A Week (the hand-claps drive me nuts)Every Little ThingYou Like Me Too MuchYour Mother Should KnowThe Long and Winding Road (Phil Specter version, too schmaltzy)

For me, the worst is “What Goes On.” … it is a low-water mark. Anybody could have come up with that song. It may be that it rankles most because it appears on Rubber Soul and drags that record down terribly. The American version of Rubber Soul is, to me, a masterpiece (whether the Beatles cared for it or not, the Capitol Records marketing machine actually got something right for once.) And when all the albums were reissued as CDs, I was excited until I saw that Rubber Soul was the English version—missing two songs that I feel worked well on the American RS, but also containing “Nowhere Man” (not a bad get) “If I Needed Someone,” Also not bad, certainly worthy of the rest of the record. I’ve never cared for “Drive My Car” which is not an A-team Beatles song in my opinion, much less a good candidate as a lead-off tune for an otherwise great record, But then you have “What Goes On” … a mess of a thing with little reason to exist than… except to provide a vehicle for Ringo to sing one in the set. They should have canned “What Goes On” completely. Someone else said “Don’t Pass Me By” is the worst and that has a lot sense to it… it IS badly played and badly recorded and badly produced and badly sung and badly written. But at least it doesn't stand out like a gaping headwound in the very middle of one of the Beatles’ best albums.

there is an extremely small handful of songs that I don’t like. I have listened to the Beatles since high school(along other 60’s acts such as the rolling stones, doors, jimi hendrix, the who, beach boys and etc). the beatles are probably the only band that I enjoyed about almost 100% of their material. however, there are 6 songs I disliked: Run for your life: the song was poorly played, had lackluster production and it had strange dark lyrics that talk about murder: “I’d rather see you dead little girl than be with another man”. Good Night: I didn’t like this song not because of ringo(ringo starr puts on a really good preformance), its just that it seemed to melancholy. “Good Night” also proves that Ringo’s voice fits in with really sombre or sad tunes. Oh! Darling: Never liked this one because it seemed like the Beatles attempted Screamo nearly 40 years before it was invented. Maxwell’s Silver Hammer: Dark and weird song about a murdering psychopath. I think Paul got really carried away with pop standards, show tunes and so called “granny songs”. Revolution 9: not really a song per say, but rather a collection of noise the Long Winding road(album version): again, Spector overproduced this track making a sorry mess of a song. there really is no worst Beatles songs. But in my opinion it would have to be run for your life or Revolution 9

I have to go with “Piggies.” First of all, it’s a truly dreadful song with awful playing and insipid misanthropic lyrics that attempt to satirize American culture and/or attempt to start some kind of counterculture revolution. It really depends on whether you view the whole thing as an attempt at satire or not. The trouble is it is so boring and heavy-handed, you don’t end up caring. That harpsichord is awful also. Second, Charles Manson was inspired by this song to commit mass murder, showing, if nothing else, that the song has really bad karma. But worst of all is this. According to the Beatles’ associate producer Chris Thomas, Harrison at one point during the song’s recording session broke off playing Piggies and started playing a beautiful melody on the harpsichord. Thomas was enthused and asked Harrison pointedly, “Why don’t we do that one instead?” Harrison declined, claiming the song really wasn’t ready, and the recording of Piggies went ahead. The song that Harrison turned down in order to record this monstrous bad version of a high school book report on 1984 was …. “Something.” Thankfully Harrison later completed “Something”, which justly became one of the great rock ballads of all time. And to think it almost got scuttled for this . That alone is enough to make “Piggies” my least favorite Beatles song.

Baby´s in black - boredom in 6/8. terrible lyrics. useless and annoying. Am I the only one who hates this? (for sale)Misery …..a terrible original that sounds like someone else has written it. But John is to blame for this. We call this attitude “Gejammer” in german. (Please,please me)When I´m 64 - well, granny music (Pepper)I´m happy just to dance with you (A hard days night) - Shite lyrics, sung by George, boring melody, piece of crapAct naturally (Help) - just to give Ringo a song - useless track written by someone I don´knowRun for your life - like “when I´m 64” the one crap song on a perfect album (Rubber Soul)Ob-la-di ….. my granny loved it (white)Martha my dear ….oh boy, I felt asleep (white)ok…Yellow submarine is a classic and the title song but “All together now” is a children song not worth being recorded by the boys ( Yellow submarine)Maxwell´s silver hammer is simply annoying ( Abbey road)I´ve got a feeling —c´mon, this is not the Beatles ( Let it be)..I´m surprised that there are songs like Paperback Writer or Michelle are on peoples lists. I´m not surprised about No.9 - but this track was really important, introducing a great public to Stockhausens rechniques. I listened to it a 1000 times when I was eight. Probably it caused some damnage as I love free jazz today ;-)

‘Good day Sunshine’ makes my stomach lurch like a train braking to avoid a stalled van. The goopy forced cheerfulness, the soggy sing-along rhythm, the inane lyrics: “I need to laugh, and when the sun is out I’ve got something to laugh about, I feel good, in a special way. I’m in love and it’s a sunny day.” Need to purge? Why bother with a finger when you’ve got something like this at your disposal? Of course music is personal, and as such I’m a bit horrified at the songs folks dislike. Here’s my defense of a few: ‘Ob La Di Ob La Da’ isn’t a fave, but at least it’s got a little life to it. ‘Revolution Number Nine’ was an attempt at musical collage. I don’t particularly like it but I’d rather have pretension falling on its face than sugar-dipped daisies hammered into my ear. The serial killer lyrics of ‘Maxwell’s Silver Hammer’ is what makes the song interesting, not its problem. Did you have a childhood? Then how can you hate ‘Octopuses Garden’ or ‘Yellow Submarine’? ‘Run for Your Life’ is a song about a guy with a diseased mind: “Well you know that I’m a wicked guy/and was born with a jealous mind” and as such was not created to to provide spiritual guidance or to offer any relationship advice whatsoever. It’s important to consider context when hearing a song like ‘Her Majesty’. At the time the world was proclaiming The Beatles to be musical gods; a whole generation waited on their every utterance. From the beginning they showed a willingness to poke fun at themselves, and surely that willingness was a reason they survived such over the top fame. Many don’t. Ending a mind-searing masterpiece with a simple ditty proclaiming an undying love for the Queen and the plaint “I want to tell her I love her a lot but I got to get a belly full of wine” reminds us of their humanity. The Beatles were were constantly dethroning themselves. Unlike other bands I love, Pink Floyd say, The Beatles were determined to include us. What can you say to four boys like that other than thank you?

Funny how tastes differ. I read some of these others and I want to write, Oh, come on, it’s not that bad….Anyway, here is my list. Happy listening…I guess. I think “When I Get Home” is just horrible. Although its bridge makes me laugh, I don’t think they were trying to make me laugh. It sounds like they were going for some kind of Otis Redding southern soul song; and it’s not that they fail, because failing would be understandable. After all, they were just not that kind of band. It’s that they ALMOST succeed and that is what makes it so terrible. I like the pounding drums and the chunky guitars and it definitely has a cow-bell but the off-key vocals, the silly lyrics and the song just seems framed wrong: it’s melody is uncharacteristically down-played and just doesn’t work. If it had been 1965 they would have recut it it with a totally different arrangement, I think.“Hold Me Tight.” I don’t really know if the song is bad, per se — Phil Spector’s version actually turned it into an enjoyable piece of throwaway pop; but the performance/production is wretched. Off-key, almost bored-sounding vocals, annoying handclaps, a slagging tempo. It’s chugging intro sounds good for about five seconds but the track goes steadily downhill from there.One of the great things about the Beatles is that they almost always all seem to be giving 100%. But not on this song.“You Like Me Too Much.” Like everything they did, it’s not completely horrid. I like the piano/organ intro and the guitar/piano solo. But geez. That bridge that starts “I really do…”may be the most bored any major band has ever sounded on anything.. “Wild Honey Pie”. One of the great things about the White Album is that, in context, the sequencing of the album is such that even totally annoying pieces of grating avant-pop like this one sound kind of cool. This is the sound of babies being put through meat grinders, like in that Pink Floyd video.“Maxwell’s Silver Hammer.” It’s got all the elements of a good song: clever lyrics, an inventive arrangement, good production and performance from all involved, a cracking lead guitar and even a cool moog synth solo. They worked so hard on this that I feel almost guilty about relegating to Sucksville, but that’s where it goes.

So many people adding such lengthy answers about the objectivity of their catalogue and how a bad song can’t be real because someone might like it. I’ll lay it down for you, the Beatles had 13 albums and over 200 songs. There’s bound to be something bad in there. I personally think the worst of it comes from two albums: The White Album and Let it Be. I know they’re more stripped back albums, and lots of people genuinely love the White Album and think it’s the Beatles best work, but you have to admit there’s a lot of filler on that one. Wild Honey Pie is a hot piece of garbage. Don’t get me wrong, I love Paul. I love him more than I love probably any other celebrity or figure in music. This song just ain’t it though. I really like Why Don’t We Do it in the Road. That song at least has some bite to it and is kind of edgy, but Wild Honey Pie is just a bunch of noise. I wouldn’t even call it inventive just because it’s so weird. I genuinely hate it whenever it comes on. Revolution 9 is so bad I don’t think anybody even considers it a song. This song terrifies me. If you listen to Revolution 9 at night in the dark, it’s an experience in and of itself. I get scared that I’ll turn on the light and John and Yoko will be staring right at me with wicked smiles on their faces. I know some people actually like this “song”, but I can’t imagine why that is. It’s just a bunch of self indulgent noise that we all wish could be erased from the Beatles catalogue. Everything else on the White Album goes from passable to downright amazing. Maggie Mae bothers me because it’s not even a finished song. It’s really just a jam session that got cut short and made it on the Let it Be album. That song belongs on one of the Anthology albums and thats it. It’s a shame too because I actually like the song (even though it’s a cover) and if they had taken the time to actually do it right it would be pretty good. There’s really no wonder why it was omitted from Let it Be…Naked. Everything else on Let it Be is pretty good but could have been recorded better (and I think Phil Spectors work on it wasn’t good and that Paul was right to make Let it Be…Naked to show how it could have been. Spectors version of the Long and Winding Road is just too busy and not emotional enough for me. When Paul sings “long and winding rooooad” and then BAM the orchestra comes in, it catches me by surprise and just feels too loud. I hate it). I’m sure there’s more that could be added but those three songs to me just barely count as songs at all but were still released as if they were. If they never existed, the world would be no different (except for maybe Revolution 9 but I’d argue the world would be better if it was Yesterday’d and everyone forgot about it). If you want my opinion on songs that are generally liked that I don’t really enjoy and have an unpopular opinion on, I don’t think “Rain” is that good even though everyone loves it, but even then I wouldn’t consider it a bad song. It all really comes down to personal taste.

Everyone will have their own such list. Here’s five that just don’t cut the mustard: “I Wanna Be Your Man”—Ringo needed a solo track on each early album, but the song is a tedious throwaway, and Lennon/McCartney had superior material sitting around that would’ve worked much better. It isn’t horrible—it’s just dull.“If You’ve Got Troubles”—unissued for many years, this is another sub-standard original given to Ringo. It’s a mess, and it was wise of the group not to issue it.“The Night Before”—a below-par song tossed off for the “Help!” movie, this is a regressive piece that sounds more like something Gerry Marsden would have written (he of Gerry & the Pacemakers, a lightweight Liverpool beat group). From any other group, it would seem okay; from the Beatles, it’s strictly mehs-ville.“That Means a Lot”—a coy, pretentious McCartney song that is overfull of clever, hey-looka-me chord changes. It’s ambitious, but it doesn’t gel. The band was, again, wise to shelve this one and move on to better things.“Maxwell’s Silver Hammer”/”Ob-La-Di”—I may hate the latter a bit more, but both songs are examples of the air-headed side of Paul McCartney, and if I never hear either again, my life will be that much better.

Don’t Pass Me By is pretty bad, but it does give us interesting lyrics. I have always thought that the clues about Paul being dead were only half of the story… that nearly always they were followed up by lyrics that let us know he came back to life… as Jesus did… Remember Jesus? They were torched for supposedly thinking they were better than Jesus… So what would four guys do about that accusation and all the crap they had to go through for John’s off-hand comment? I think what they did was they hid things in their lyrics that hinted at Paul died and came back to life… So when Ringo sings, “You were in a car crash and you lost your hair.” he follows that up with, “You said that you would be late… about an hour or two… I said, ‘that’s all right I’m waiting here, just waiting to hear from you.” Another one I really loved because I had this theory before the song came out, was “He blew his mind out in a car. He didn’t notice that the lights had changed.” That was pointed out as being more clues that Paul was dead. However, it was followed up by “Nobody was really sure if he was from the House Of Lords.” Then, of course, Mother Mary came to Paul, right? Another little clue that could indicate they were making Paul a Christ figure came at the end of “All You Need Is Love” You can hear the melody of “What Child Is This?” fading out at the end of the song. Paul and the rest of the Beatles on Abbey Road are walking AWAY from the grave yard. There are other clues. It just makes sense to me that these guys would have lashed back at the angry world for being so unfairly maligned, and what better way to do that than to embed clues in their songs? But I digress. Don’t Pass Me By is not a good song, but it doesn’t hurt the side of the album. It’s a silly sing a long type ditty. However, it has way more substance than “Your Mother Should Know”… I have no idea how Paul got the Beatles to do that horrible video of that song. It’s almost sad to see them all having no fun whatsoever during that thing. So, long story/short, my vote is for “Your Mother Should Know.”

Most of the "bad" Beatles songs can be split into three categories: Ringo Starr compositions: Don't Pass Me ByOctopus' Garden(Ringo sang lead on a few other songs, i.e. Yellow Submarine, Boys; but these are the two songs he wrote himself, and quite poorly) Throwaway tracks from the brilliant but inconsistent Let It Be: Dig ItMaggie MaeCoversThese might technically fall outside of the "Beatles songs" category, but the Beatles recorded quite a few covers on their studio albums, mostly the early ones. Generally they covered songs they liked as kids, and often these songs - especially the Carl Perkins and Chuck Berry covers - were a poor fit for their musical style and ability. The most notable of these: Devil in Her HeartA Taste of HoneyMr. Moonlight(Full list at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_songs_covered_by_The_Beatles) Honorable Mentions: PiggiesOb-La-Di Ob-La-Da (I might catch some flack for this, but I think this song is wildly overrated.)All things considered, there were incredibly few "bad" songs written during their seven-year run.

Literally can’t resist answering this question:) How subjective music is - people have even answered Within You Without You - which is Pepper’s highpoint along with A Day in the Life. It is the only track on Pepper I am actually moved by. Maxwell and Ob La Di? Thanks Paul for being open minded enough to create 2 bonkers songs no-one else would dare write. The breadth of vision is, of course, why The Beatles are the greatest band of all time. If George and John had had their way of being more rock the Beatles would have collapsed into a more narrow beast like most other bands. Someone put Tomorrow Never Knows down - gives me goosebumps everytime still. I used to do music concrete for fun as a teenager so love Revolutiion #9 because it’s not a song of course - it’s a proper bit of mid to late 60s experimentalism. Paul was the big one for that and it’s a shame it was only John who sneaked one onto a Beatles album. Music is subjective so it’s cool some don’t like these tracks but a bit of a shocker when such dross as Don’t Pass Me By, What Goes On, Dig It, Flying and Run For Your Life are available to hate on!

Well we all know it is subjective so here are my 5. There are other Beatles songs I don’t like much but these are the ones that I always press “skip” when I am playing the cd. Revolution 9 Over 40 years I have tried. really tried to find some merit in it but no, to me it is just a self indulgent noise. Mr Moonlight The opening scream by Lennon is fantastic. Then it becomes this Bosa Nova song that I can imagine being used in the background of a 1960s TV programme like the Saint to show that he is in some club somewhere abroad. When I’m 64 Surely THE low point of Sgt Pepper’s. This so called revolutionary psychedelic album dips into a novelty song about being 64 with Paul’s voice speeded up to make him younger. I first this heard when I was about 10 and loved it. Then I grew up! Hold me Close Just sluggish and Paul is really out of tune in some places Till There Was You A very obvious attempt to repeat the formula of A Taste of Honey from the previous album. The “Beatles as all round entertainers “ on middle of the road tv programmes at the time. I didn’t include Maggie Mae as its so short its over by the time I find the remote!

I’ll give you my three (since they don’t seem to be anyone else’s least favourite Beatles songs from looking at the other answers): From their early period: If I Fell (from A Hard Day’s Night). Just appalling schmaltz. I may begrudgingly admit that John and Paul do some nice two-part harmonies, but the song is terrible. Even the boys themselves used to make fun of it when they played it live, sometimes introducing it as If I Fell Over.From their middle period: Blue Jay Way (from Magical Mystery Tour). A dismal dirge of a song. I can literally find nothing positive to say about this track whatsoever.From their late period: The Continuing Story of Bungalow Bill (from the White Album). On an album with a number of low points, this track stands out for how crap it is. It sounds like a bunch of people messing around in the studio, throwing something together in a few minutes of free time for their own amusement. No one else should have ever been made to listen to it.

In general, I am a big fan of the entire Beatles catalogue, and the shear diversity of their song styles and genres only makes me appreciate them more. That said, one of their songs annoys the crap out of me every time I hear it, and always has – “Why Don’t We Do It In The Road?” When I was young, the song was controversial in the conservative area where I lived because of the straightforward sexual connotation. That has never bothered me. What irritates me about the “song” is that it’s nothing more than repeating the exact same “Why Don’t We Do It In The Road?” phrase 15 times, interrupted by also repeating “No one will be watching us” 3 times, for 1:46. This poor excuse for a song particularly galls me because it’s not by some band known for churning out pointless, empty crap – as many do – it’s by the band that put out brilliantly lyrical storytelling like Strawberry Fields Forever, A Day In The Life, Eleanor Rigby, She’s Leaving Home, and Nowhere Man, as well as thought-provoking songs like Tomorrow Never Knows, Blackbird, Help!, and Hey Jude, and uplifting classics like All You Need is Love, Here Comes the Sun, Here There and Everywhere, The End, etc., etc., etc. After all of that and more, “Why Don’t We Do It In The Road?” doesn’t come close to measuring up lyrically, musically, or attitudinally.

The worst (in my humble opinion, of course): Little child: Formulaic pop at its top tastelessness. I Wanna Be Your Man: Formulaic rockabilly sung by Ringo. You Like Me Too Much: The climax of lame lack of inspiration. The Inner Light: George was so excited about Indian music, but at that time failed to produce stg even remotely memorable. Blue Jay Way: George was surely able to write about nothing. Filler. Savoy Truffle: George was surely able to write about nothing #2. Don’t Pass Me By: Ringo's strength was NOT composition. Embarrassing. Revolution 9: Self-indulgent nothingness with the horrid pseudo-avant-garde Yoko. Sun King: those pseudo-Latin words (Spanish, Italian, Portuguese) make me cringe. I couldn't include anything of Rubber Soul and Revolver because those two albums were the heavenly soundtrack of my childhood in the dismal Brazilian Savannah. Just for comparison: I love dozens of Beatles songs, and Across the Universe is my fave.

There has to be one, of course, but I wouldn’t care to name one. It’s testament to the Beatles’ greatness that in a short career they generated a huge catalogue of recordings covering a wide range of styles from pure pop to the avant-garde, with very few duffs. Some tracks probably shouldn’t have made it to the relevant album. Maggie Mae, the traditional Liverpool sailor’s song I always imagine the lads singing after a few bevvies in the Grapes following a Cavern gig, perhaps, but that’s what happens when you work with Phil Spector. That was always going to end in tears. But it follows Let It Be, which wasn’t intended to be their epitaph but in practice it was, and the snippet links the epitaph back to their origins, which on reflection is a piece of brilliance on Spector’s part. The two tracks should have ended the album though; it works best if you switch the two sides round. (interesting that the “official” epitaph is capped by an accidental snippet too, though not one as significant as this one. In retrospect I think the most regrettable Beatles song is Run For Your Life.

I was pedantically replying to another answer that his list should at least contain these songs, but since I got over eight, I’ll post the list as yet another answer: Older songs that just don’t live up to The Beatles’ standard Little ChildTell Me WhyEvery Little ThingWhen I joke doesn’t work (B-side) You Know My NameThe worst of the worst album Only A Northern SongYou think it would grow on you, but no Wild Honey PieThe reason I didn’t want to listen to the Abbey Road Album Maxwell’s Silver HammerShouldn’t have been on the Let It Be album and one of the reasons I prefer the Naked version. Dig ItMaggie MaeThe answer I was replying to complained about Paul’s granny songs, but I actually like them. My list contains mostly fillers and Maxwell’s Silver Hammer, the granny song that I really can’t stand.

Of course, it would be an exaggeration to say, “there is no worst Beatle song.” Generally, the thing with any worst song is that everyone hates it, nobody care to listen to it, or it is simply so bad. But the worst song doesn't necessarily need to have the above aspects. To me, the worst would be Hello, Goodbye. The song is criminally overrated, if not worst. I would feel so embarrassed to recommend this song to new listeners, the lyrics are so dumb and repetitive, and even tune is pretty mediocre. I feel like in hell, they may play this song to torture sinners. The worst part is that this song has 100m+ views on Youtube and 74m+ plays on Spotify. The popularity of this is annoying, so much views and plays to an objectively mediocre song.

Surprised by a lot of the answers on here, particularly as a lot of the songs are personal faves (“Don’t pass me by” and “Wild Honey Pie” for instance). Here’s my ‘bottom’ 5. Run for your Life – nasty, misogynistic crap. Even Lennon hated it.You Know My Name (Look up the Number) – Every time I listen to this, I’m convinced it’s deliberately bad, like a middle finger to the audience.I Don’t Want to Spoil the Party – Sounds twee, with bland lyrics. It’s like a bad parody of a lot of their songs of the period.It’s All Too Much – Essentially based around a repeated single line, there’s nothing of interest here and it stands out as the nadir of what was one of their weakest albums anyway.(Going to get some heat for this one) Magical Mystery Tour – Sounds perpetually out of tune, gets repetitive, and the general concept was done far better with “Being for the Benefit of Mr Kite”. Thoroughly disposable.All of this of course ignoring the awkward Christmas singles and “Free as a Bird”.

“Run for Your Life” is a catchy song sung from a sick perspective. I don’t mind it. I love Paul’s granny’s music, they are refreshing amidst John’s edginess. The weird oddities that can hardly be called normal song are sometimes refreshing too. “Obladi, Oblada”, I imagine had this song came out earlier people wouldn’t have hated it this much. It’s not that bad. So…I will go for songs that annoy me without excuse. There are two ‘good’ songs that is not that good, “Good Morning Good Morning” and “Good Day Sunshine”. The first have terribly annoying verse but forgiveable chorus, the latter is the other way around. Both of them annoy me. Other songs that I can not enjoy is “Within You Without You”, it’s so self-indulgent and feel sophomoric, a waste of precious minute in an already weirldy-paced album. And I love George and his Indian musical influence. Lastly, I can’t really stand “I Will”. It sounded beautiful but out of place in first hearing, then the beauty quickly faded while it remains out of place. I’m an album listener, these four songs are probably not so awful in themselves, but they always sound disruptive and I don’t need them when I listen to the albums that contain them.

If I remember right John and Paul wrote around three hundred songs together. What we got to hear was about one hundred of their songs. So I'm guessing those other two hundred songs sucked. Yeah, Mr. Moonlight is a weird song, but I like weird, especially that sick organ solo. I love that sound that they got on the organ for that song. They might of wrote Mr. Moonlight for their cartoon show for the kids ( I never missed those cartoons as a kid). Yeah growing up with The Beatles was a great experience. Once they hit the Ed Sullivan Show, America and the world had a great musical ride for many years to come…

I’m listening to Revolver as I type this and as much as the heavy Indian and psychedelic influences get a little old after the 3rd song featuring a sitar, nothing compares to the mediocrity of Yellow Submarine. How on earth John and Paul caved into agreeing to put that ridiculous song on the album boggles my mind. The melody sounds like a 5th grade, beginning piano student decided to attempt to write a song. It’s that bad. It’s so underwhelming that maybe John and Paul thought “ what the heck , let’s put something really childish on this album just for fun. “ From what I read , yellow submarine was voted the worst Beatles song by thousands of fans so I’m not alone. Otherwise Revolver is a fantastic album- to me the second best after Rubber Soul.

More appropriately songs. A bunch were recorded half heartedly for the Yellow Submarine album and these included All Together Now, Only A Northern Song, Its All Too Much and Hey Bulldog. These songs were not the "top shelf" standard of previous Beatle releases and never saw light again 'til a compilation album was released in the late seventies. Of the main Beatle LP releases perhaps songs such as Why Don't We Do It In The Road or Don't Pass Me By from the White album would rate lowly in any Beatles opinion poll as they were included probably as "making up numbers" for that largely fine album. Some people might argue that George Harrison's contributions on Revolver (Love You Too) and Sergeant Pepper (Within You And Without You) were not as stylistically effective as the other songs on those respective albums. Again, these reflections are just my earnest opinions and other people are may agree or disagree with the aforementioned statements,

To answer this question correctly, I have to preface it by saying that “worst Beatles song“ depends on the personal preference of each listener. Therefore, I don’t believe there is a universal “worst” song, not only of the Beatles, but of any artist. That said, the Beatles song I dislike the most is ‘What’s The New Mary Jane’. But there are others I’m not particularly fond of, such as ‘You Like Me Too Much’, ‘Blue Jay Way’, ‘Wild Honey Pie’, ‘Honey Pie’, ‘The Continuing Story Of Bungalow Bill’, ‘Don’t Pass Me By’, ‘It’s Only A Northern Song’, ‘It’s All Too Much’ ‘Yellow Submarine’ and ‘All Together Now’ I’m sure those are liked by others, but, for me, they just don’t cut it.

Revolution 9. Created by John Lennon and Yoko Ono, the eight minutes of tape loops, noises, screaming, feedback and other effects mixed in with producer George Martin saying “Number 9, number 9, number 9” over and over again makes this the Beatles longest — and by far the worst — “song.” It’s so bad that McCartney, Harrison and Ringo joined forces to try to prevent it from appearing on the White Album, but to no avail.

The three original compositions that immediately come to mind as truly poor are Dig It, Wild Honey Pie, and the worst of all, Revolution 9. Even the worst of the rest is still good music. For me personally, some of the most highly acclaimed and beautiful songs they ever recorded are the songs I skip over. Maybe it’s because they were so overplayed, or maybe it’s just me because these are indeed great songs. I’m speaking of songs like The Long and Winding Road, Hey Jude, Let It Be, and yes, even Yesterday. Note that the first three were all Phil Specter productions which I think is more than coincidence. Reading other answers, I am surprised to see some songs named that I genuinely like…… Glass Onion, Maxwell’s, Octopus’ Garden, and Piggies among others.

What is the worst Beatles song? I haven’t been a Beatles fan my entire life, but I’ve always had the sense that they were just straight-up goofballs. Their sense of humor is one of the things I love about them, along with their willingness to experiment. Sure, not all of their experiments succeeded, but that’s just how it works. And it was the ‘60s. So while I don’t hold their failed experiments against them, I do have to acknowledge that they were flops. There are very few of their songs that I just plain don’t like, so this will be a rather short list. In no particular order: Run for Your Life. Musically, it’s good. It’s catchy. Lyrically, I just can’t get behind the misogyny. Revolution 9. This was their experiment that fell flat. It was an interesting novelty the first few listens, but these days I tend to skip it more often than not when it comes up in the rotation. What’s the New Mary Jane? I think they were going somewhere with it musically, but the lyrics only drag it down further. Honorable mention: She’s a Woman. I disliked the dissonant chords when I was younger, although it’s grown on me somewhat, kind of like how bitter-flavored things become more palatable with age.

That’s a very subjective list. I happen to like the inventive synth solo on Maxwell’s Silver Hammer, and don’t mind some cheesy schmaltz (When I’m 64). The Night Before is one of my favorite songs! Oh well. Revolution #9. It’s just painful and empty. I suppose it’s good that the Beatles were experimenting. But it’s positively unpleasant to listen to.Run for your life. Creepy and mean. Even Lennon regretted writing it.Yer blues. You’re not a blues band. And it’s a stupid song.The word. The word is—you’ll never guess—love. With a shrill, harsh, hissing organ track that’s way too loud.Girl. It’s my bias that I just don’t like Rubber Soul, and find its folksy sound trying too hard. The ‘girl’ is a bitch who likes to hurt people. Why immortalize her in this faux-gypsy dirge?

Goodbye Hello - tediously repetitive. Never really understood why this flimsy song was a single. Ballad of John and Yoko - far too self indulgent Within You Without You - I think I managed to listen all the way through once, really disrupts the flow of Sgt Peppers Revolution No 9 - might have worked if it was much shorter, but it has no structure Goodnight - Paul gets flack for his sentimentality but John could be worse Why Don’t We Do It In The Road - should have been left off the White Album Don’t Pass Me By - ditto You Know My Name - the Goon Show influences come through, but just plain silly What’s the New Mary Jane - too stoned

I have only heard about 100 of The Beatles’ songs, but I can’t think of any that grate on me. I used to dislike Hello, Goodbye, but I watched a live version by McCartney a few years ago and I kind of got it a bit more… and it has a nice ending sequence. Old Brown Shoe is not great in my opinion. But I like lots of the other people’s choices of worst. For instance I love Honey Pie, Within You Without You, Mr Moonlight and Maxwell’s Silver Hammer. I don’t think I have heard Revolution 9 or Maggie Mae so I couldn’t comment.

Revolution 9: This song is John's poor attempt on creating avant garde music, too odd and too creepy. The Ballad of John and Yoko: This song annoys me because it's full of rants, although I enjoy Paul's drumming there. Run For Your Life: Too harsh and too sarcastic, John was ranting some kind of irrational jealousy on this song. Wild Honey Pie: Too vapid and annoying Maxwell's Silver Hammer: This song is annoying, vapid, and over the top. No wonder John, George, and Ringo dislike this song.

Blue Jay Way - Dreary and monotonous Hello, Goodbye - Dumb lyrics, written not to say anything but just to be an empty pop hit. Pepper it always seems to sag in the middle, with the low point being She’s Leaving Home, with its horrid string arrangement and overly plaintive vocal. Others certainly don’t stand on their own (“Wild Honey Pie”!) but work as connecting filler between much better songs.

for me—”I don’t want to Spoil the Party” and especially, “EIGHT DAYS A WEEK”—-I think they were put on the album, (BEATLES VI-AMERICAN RELEASE) as filler—written to fill out the record contract—absolutely miserable mushy sub-par garbage-AND with the exception of WORDS OF LOVE, WHAT YOU’RE DOING, YES, IT IS—this album is the WORST Beatles album EVER— also-I can’t understand why folks hate “REVOLUTION #9” get ripped people and play it backwards AND—it’s really a studio/ engineer piece anyway—not a true Beatles song.

Putting on my Dan Aykroyd/Leonard Pinth-Garnell voice... The B-side of the Let It Be single, You Know My Name (Look Up The Number), is monumentally bad.  It is exquisitely awful, and it is surely one of the most perfectly ill-conceived pieces of bad music ever to have passed through a woofer and tweeter and into unsuspecting human ears.

“Dig It”  I think I wouldn’t have such a problem with “Dig It” if it were longer. But in its standard form, it’s a jam without the jam. Any charm it may have had is ruined by being so truncated that it verges on meaninglessness. The only thing I like about it is a high-pitched John Lennon saying “Hark, the Angels Come” at the end, which I’ll admit is the perfect segue into “Let It Be”. Even “Maggie Mae” (which seems to be pretty unpopular from other answers to this question) is a complete performance of its arrangement. “Dig It” doesn’t even come in with any context. I know Glyn Johns intended for a longer excerpt of the jam to be released on Get Back, and perhaps I’d appreciate that extension, but in Spector’s edit, there’s no point for “Dig It”.

In 1971, the Village Voice and WPLJ in New York asked fans to vote for their five least favorite Beatles songs.
